pred:

The second thing to look for is a lung opacity.  This is a more challenging finding, since it must be seen and then, if it is a pulmonary edema, must be differentiated from other causes.  This is where the support devices, fractures, and pneumothorax come into play.  If there is a support device present and it has failed recently (within the past 24-48 hours), then pulmonary embolism becomes a concern, and the workup should include a CT of the chest.

-Left ventricular hypertrophy
-Left atrial enlargement
-Premature ventricular contractions (if the catheter has been inadvertently placed in the right ventricle)

The pathophysiology behind the wedge-shaped consolidation is complete vascular occlusion cutting off blood supply to lung tissue, causing infarction. There is also aadrenergic dilation of the pulmonary artery afterload that further increases the pressure in the pulmonary artery.
